Expectation1: Communicate politely and professionally with customers
Situation1: The customer asks about the delivery status
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A community member casually mentioned wanting advice whenever the imam has free time.
Story: I was rushing through my delivery route, my phone buzzing with notifications. As a delivery person, I knew customers expected quick, polite responses, so when a customer texted, “Where’s my package?” I pulled over and typed a courteous reply, assuring them I was on my way. Just then, my other phone vibrated—a message from a community member at the mosque. “Imam, I’d love to talk when you have a moment. I need some advice,” it read. I felt a familiar tug inside me. As an imam, I was expected to be available, to listen and offer guidance, especially when someone reached out for help. But right now, I was in my delivery uniform, with a van full of packages and a schedule to keep. My mind raced, torn between the customer waiting for their order and the community member seeking spiritual support. Both needed me, both expected me to be present and attentive. I stared at my phones, feeling the weight of their expectations pressing in from both sides, unsure which role to answer first.
